docs.lead_paragraph: In upholding President Obama’s health care plan, the chief justice made two incompatible arguments.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law professor Richard A Epstein criticizes the Supreme Court decision upholding the health care reform law; contends that Chief Justice John G Roberts's majority opinion contained two incompatible arguments, and undermines his ruling, the court and the Constitution.
docs.snippet: In upholding President Obama’s health care plan, the chief justice made two incompatible arguments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly half of recently retired officers in a survey said they had “personal knowledge” of crime-report manipulation, but the Police Department questioned the study’s methodology.

headline.seo: New York Police Department Manipulates Crime Reports, Study Finds
headline.main: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Crime Report Manipulation Is Common Among New York Police, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Anonymous survey of nearly 2,000 retired New York City Police Officers finds that manipulation of crime reports has long been part of the culture of the department; Police Dept officials criticize the methodology of the study, led by Prof Eli B Silverman of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, and question the reliability of the findings.
docs.snippet: Nearly half of recently retired officers in a survey said they had “personal knowledge” of crime-report manipulation, but the Police Department questioned the study’s methodology.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. carefully took on what a predecessor called the grave task of assessing the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress.

headline.seo: Health Care Is Defining Decision for Chief Justice Roberts
headline.main: Roberts Shows Deft Hand as Swing Vote on Health Care
headline.sub: Conservative Chief Justice’s Vote Shows a Delicate Hand

docs.abstract: News analysis; Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr, in a surprise Supreme Court ruling that goes against his conservative leanings, carefully accepted what a predecessor called the grave task of assessing the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress; in upholding President Obama’s health care overhaul law, he performed the task with exquisite delicacy.
docs.snippet: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. carefully took on what a predecessor called the grave task of assessing the constitutionality of a law passed by Congress.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: With the central pillar of his agenda left intact, President Obama may yet join the ranks of presidents who fundamentally altered the course of the country.

headline.seo: Health Care Ruling and Obama’s Place in History
headline.main: A Vindication, With a Legacy Still Unwritten
headline.print_headline: A Vindication, With a Legacy Still Unwritten

docs.abstract: Supreme Court’s health care ruling is not just political vindication for Barack Obama, who staked his presidency on a once-in-a-generation reshaping of the social welfare system, it is a personal reprieve; it leaves intact his hopes of joining the ranks of Franklin D Roosevelt, Lyndon B Johnson and Ronald Reagan as presidents who fundamentally altered the course of the country; for all its weight, however, the judgment does little to settle the bitter debate, spanning decades, over the proper role of government in American life.
docs.snippet: With the central pillar of his agenda left intact, President Obama may yet join the ranks of presidents who fundamentally altered the course of the country.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said the expansion of Medicaid in the health care law was an option, not a mandate, and experts disagreed on whether states would take it.

headline.main: Uncertainty Over States and Medicaid Expansion
headline.print_headline: Uncertainty Over States And Medicaid Expansion

docs.abstract: One of the most important questions raised by the Supreme Court's ruling on the Affordable Care Act is whether states will choose to take part in the law's massive expansion of Medicaid; while upholding the expansion of Medicaid, the Court limited the power of the federal government to secure compliance by penalizing states that refuse to go along; expansion is a central component of the law, accounting for roughly half of all the uninsured people expected to gain coverage.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court said the expansion of Medicaid in the health care law was an option, not a mandate, and experts disagreed on whether states would take it.

docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of major insurers suffered a modest dip on Thursday, while pharmaceutical and device companies fell slightly, and hospital stocks rose.

headline.seo: In Health Care Ruling, Investors See a Mixed Blessing
headline.main: In Health Care Ruling, Investors See a Mixed Blessing

docs.abstract: Shares of major insurers suffer a modest dip in the wake of the Supreme Court's ruling upholding the nation's health care overhaul bill; stocks of pharmaceutical and device companies fall slightly, while hospital stocks rise.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: In a striking victory for President Obama and Congressional Democrats, the chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., affirmed the central legislative pillar of Mr. Obama’s term.

headline.main: Supreme Court Upholds Health Care Law, 5-4, in Victory for Obama
headline.sub: Victory for Obama, but Ruling Limits Medicaid Provision
headline.print_headline: Justices, By 5-4, Uphold Health Care Law; Roberts In Majority; Victory For Obama

docs.abstract: Supreme Court upholds President Obama’s health care overhaul law, saying its requirement that most Americans obtain insurance or pay a penalty was authorized by Congress’s power to levy taxes; vote is 5 to 4, with Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr joining the court’s four more liberal members; decision is a victory for Obama and Congressional Democrats; court substantially limits the law’s expansion of Medicaid, the joint federal-state program that provides health care to poor and disabled people.
docs.snippet: In a striking victory for President Obama and Congressional Democrats, the chief justice, John G. Roberts Jr., affirmed the central legislative pillar of Mr. Obama’s term.
